results.content: This is a great course!  I am new to NextJS and I came away from this course with a good understanding of NextJS.  The course is well organized and the instructor is praiseworthy!

results.content: Variety of the content is good and many things to learn. I just don't see the point of using redux just for switching loading state.
results.content_html: Variety of the content is good and many things to learn. I just don't see the point of using redux just for switching loading state.

results.content: First, these lessons are for mid developers, and really not for juniors. It is very hard to follow these lessons, because some files are missed, some variables in the video have different values than the teacher's. I don't understand how to record so badly lessons. For example: a variable is true, then at some point the teacher changes it to false, but you are not told about this and you have the error, but at the same time you see the different result in the video lesson, of course without any errors and after checking github with the final version, you understand why. It was very annoying. Also, I think that the teacher doesn’t use Redux properly. For example: you are logged in, all data of the user is stored in Redux and if you are in Home page and try go to the another pagination page, we go to the db to get the user's information again and again, although we have this information in the store. The next thing, we do not spread the initial state in the reducers, but almost always return the new object with different keys inside. It may not very bad for this small project, when we have only loading, success, error and data variables, but I think the right way is always to spread the initial state and then to change variables. The teacher doesn't know what difference is between the simple tag and Link. Even the simple pagination with search query is not done correctly.
results.content_html:
First, these lessons are for mid developers, and really not for juniors.

It is very hard to follow these lessons, because some files are missed, some variables in the video have different values than the teacher's. I don't understand how to record so badly lessons. For example: a variable is true, then at some point the teacher changes it to false, but you are not told about this and you have the error, but at the same time you see the different result in the video lesson, of course without any errors and after checking github with the final version, you understand why. It was very annoying.

Also, I think that the teacher doesn’t use Redux properly. For example: you are logged in, all data of the user is stored in Redux and if you are in Home page and try go to the another pagination page, we go to the db to get the user's information again and again, although we have this information in the store. The next thing, we do not spread the initial state in the reducers, but almost always return the new object with different keys inside. It may not very bad for this small project, when we have only loading, success, error and data variables, but I think the right way is always to spread the initial state and then to change variables.

The teacher doesn't know what difference is between the simple tag and Link. Even the simple pagination with search query is not done correctly.

results.content:
Ghulam never ceases to amaze me with his course offerings!
 
I have only enrolled for his two full stack development courses, and in my experience & opinion, they are hands down the best-est you could find on Udemy or any other similar platform.

I have three reasons to say so:

1. He follows a lot of best practices, doesn't take shortcuts to make things easier and writes very scalable code

2. On top of being a naturally gifted teacher who provides eloquent explanations, he is super-duper prompt at answering student queries & resolving doubts. And he just won't stop until you are clear with the doubt.

3. His material covers almost every single essential feature that you would require in a modern web app and he shows you how to do things end to end without leaving you stranded anywhere.

Unlike his NodeJS course (which is beginner friendly), his full stack development courses fall into the intermediate-advanced category. So, anyone with a basic primer can easily follow.

I have one major complain with this course in particular and that forbids me from giving it a rating of full 5 stars.

"The sound is really really low unless I plug in the headphones to listen to the lectures"

As far as I can remember, this wasn't an issue with any of his former courses.

I would strongly advise anyone looking for full stack development courses to purchase Ghulam's courses over instructors like Traversy Media , Maximilian Schwarzmuller & Ryan Dhungel's courses. 

Two things that Ghulam can do to improve his courses are:

1. Make lecture level git commits so that it's easier to follow and chances of making mistakes can be minimised.

2. Instead of copying html code from already made templates, usage of UI component library like Material UI or Ant Design would be more ideal.
